creditline: Gift of Harriet and Edson Spencer
description: inverted V-shaped top section with two square pegs; very large, thick hook below top section; with wooden base; medium finish on hook and base
text: Activity within traditional Japanese farm families typically centered around a central open hearth (irori). This massive wooden hook (jizaikake) would have been suspended from the beams of a house. Cooking kettles or an iron teapot would have been suspended over the fire by a rope attached to the hook.  This style of jizaikake is popularly referred to as Daikoku, a popular kitchen god, because its cap-like top section suggests Daikoku's hat.
title: Hook
